Reviews.Author: connoisseur852
Reviews.Content: Hotel Danieli deserves its reputation as the top hotel in Venice. It is especially suitable for those who enjoy an elegant and prestigious ambience and who appreciate culture, history and antique furnitures and fittings. The hotel is in a great location, right next to St. Markâ€™s Square and opposite the piers. It cannot be more convenient as it even has its own private landing for boats. The roof-top Restaurant Terrazza Danieli offers excellent Italian cuisine, good service and a fantastic view of Venice. Dining there is a memorable experience. The Danieli is no doubt one of the best hotels in the world and is strongly recommended to anyone who wants the best in Venice.

Reviews.Title: “Incredible accomodations and location”
Reviews.Author: serarosedc
Reviews.Content: This is by far the most amazing hotel weâ€™ve ever stayed in. The sumptuous dÃ©cor, the incredibly gracious staff, and the prime location of Hotel Danieli all provided the perfect backdrop/home base for a fun and memorable trip to Venice. We booked our room with the Starwood points program and upon arrival we were told that we had been upgraded. (It is part of the Starwood Luxury Collection.) The room: The room was large, spotless, and beautifully decorated in soft tones in the Venetian style. The walls of the bedroom/sitting room area were covered in embroidered silk in a delicate ribbon and floral pattern, and the draperies were made of the same silk. The sconces were Murano glass and the furniture was pretty and painted to complement the dÃ©cor. The bed was extremely comfortable â€“ fresh and perfectly crisp white linens for the sheets, pillow cases, and duvet cover. Good firm mattress and fluffy down pillows and duvet. Greeting us on the dresser was a bottle of wine (and glasses of course) with a handwritten note from the staff welcoming us. AND â€“ when we opened our drapes and shutters â€“ we were looking right out onto the main drag of the walkway along the main canal. (We had peace and quiet in our room despite everything being so close at hand, but are also urban dwellers and may be more accustomed to the ambient noise of a well-traveled area.) The dressing room had generous hanging space for clothes, a digital lock safe, and lots of room for both of us to get changed. (It also had the equipment to iron and plenty of choices for valet services but we didnâ€™t use any of those.) There was a mini-fridge with the usual kinds of things for purchase, but it was also stocked with complementary bottled water that was re-stocked during turndown, so we always had some to carry with us when we were out & about. The bath was pretty and also generously sized. Black & white marble floors, shower/tub combo with gauzy white curtains, double vanity with nice sundries, a fabulous scale, and lots of plush white bath linens, all refreshed during turndown service. Nice view into a little canal out the window â€“ you can actually see gondoliers going past if you open the shutter. A thick, plushy robe was hanging up for each of us, and slippers were waiting under a little chair. Turndown service: In the evenings when we had returned from our dayâ€™s outings, the room would be turned down for the night. Duvet folded back, pillows arranged, nice chocolates on the end tables, little mats on each side of the bed with our slippers laid out on them, all sundries and bath linens refreshed, the shutters and windows closed and the curtains drawn. We tend to keep things pretty tidy, but it seemed like they had straightened our things up a bit too. The building: It is a Venetian masterpiece and landmark (marble, gilding, gothic windows, Murano chandeliers, etc.) and has the history of being a former Dogeâ€™s palace. The hotel is actually a few adjacent buildings connected through the interiors by beautiful and straightforward hallways and stairways. I think there may be service elevators, but they are not for general use and anyone who canâ€™t do stairs might better check with them about accessibility. Of course as soon as you arrive in front of the hotel, porters whisk out to collect your things from you and then they magically reappear in your room. The location: Hotel Danieli has its own Vaporetto (water bus) stop right out front that was very easy for us to use, and we speak no Italian except â€œpleaseâ€� and â€œthank you.â€� (***On a trip a few years earlier, my rural-dwelling parents found the water bus much more tricky. It could be that my husband and I are accustomed to using the subway system around our own town, making it easier for us to pick this system up.) It will take you up and down the main artery of Venice and the stops are clearly marked. Leaving the hotel, turn right and youâ€™re a two minute walk from St. Markâ€™s square. Turn left and youâ€™re headed toward restaurants and other things around town. Postcard view wherever you look, and there are tons of kiosk vendors on the walkway out front for the usual kinds of inexpensive souvenirs (Pinocchio puppets, carnival masks, t-shirts, umbrellas, etc.). There were plenty of places to wander close by â€“ restaurants, exquisite shops, places to get coffee or gelato, etc. The concierge: These guys were very helpful and courteous. They seemed to recommend very tourist-oriented places (large enough to hand out postcards, etc. to the hotels). For our own preference, we had to explain to them that we preferred something off the pizza-and-pasta route (there are some marvelous ones available, but we didnâ€™t really want it for more than a lunch now & then) and they were a bit baffled that tourists might want something a bit more gourmet. They also have pretty good maps and will draw directions to whatever you might want to visit on them for you. We found the city easy enough to navigate that we picked what we wanted from our guidebook and then just went around on our own. ***Also, this is a different area of staffing, but when you order a wake-up call â€“ itâ€™s a real person! It was very charming â€“ they say buon giorno to you and tell you the time and current weather, wish you a good day, and hang up when you give them an indication that youâ€™ve got the message. The food: After some serious touring, we were pretty tired on our last night and decided to cancel our dinner reservations and just stay in and order room service. Everything turned out to be delicious, so we didnâ€™t feel like we were missing out cuisine-wise at all! Everything was delivered about 45 minutes after we ordered it. The kitchen staff spoke perfect English (as did every other member of the staff we interacted with), so ordering was very easy for us. Everything was wheeled in by porters (who discreetly did not notice that we were in our bathrobes). They swiftly set it all up and then told us to call when we wanted them to take it away. Tablecloth, candle, flowers, wine, and bread basket accompanied our various courses which were all covered with silver dome covers, except for the salad of course, which they has assembled in-room during the setup so that it would be fresh and crisp. Plenty to make me (the vegetarian in our family) happy. The Danieli has a full-service restaurant and also a breakfast buffet, but we ate all of our other meals out and about so canâ€™t comment on them. It was a spectacular stay and if we were ever to travel back ourselves or recommend to anyone looking for a special place to stay, we would stay again or suggest it to others without hesitation.

Reviews.Title: “one of the best hotels in the world.”
Reviews.Author: meron1
Reviews.Content: Hotel Danieli is one of my favorite hotels in Italy. we stayed at the Danieli for the weekend in mid summer of 2005. The hotel was built in the 14 century to meet the demands of Europe's traveling nobility. The hotel is beautifully restored to truly represent the splendor and romance of Venice, lavishly decorated with stained glass, ornately carved pink marble and gold leaf columns, murano glass chandeliers and high ceilings decorated with gold leaves. It tuely represents the reach artful Venetian culture. The hotel is just steps away from Piazza San Marco, Doge's palace. We got the 'suite lagoon view ' room on the top floor with a beautiful balcony over looking the water and the city. The room is decoreted so beautifully and gracefully reflects the warmth and rich cultural heritage of Venice. it is a five star hotel a bit pricey but it is a must see.

Reviews.Title: “Liked hotel, but ask for room in "original pink building"”
Reviews.Author: Donna222
Reviews.Content: Liked this hotel for the most part. TERRIFIC location in the heart of everything, great lobby, nice room, large closet, helpful staff. However, I did not know before I booked here that the hotel is actually two separate buildings. The "pink building" is apparently the original and has been renovated. Our room was in the "white building" next door which is connected by a ramp on the second floor. I knew the hotel was old and was looking forward to the "old world feel" of it, however for the room price ($1394/night), a 35 year old bathroom isn't quite acceptable. While I would still recommend the Danieli because of its other pluses, DEFINITELY request a room in the renovated building!! Enjoy Venice - it's wonderful.

Reviews.Title: “Danieli - Not my Favorite”
Reviews.Author: Happyfeet59
Reviews.Content: My husband and I spent several days at the Danieli in May 08, and although there is much nice to say, we would probably never consider going back. On the plus side - the location is unbeatable, right on the water by St. Mark's Square. The public rooms are very grand. There is a private water taxi stop, and the terrace has the best view in the city. Luxury touches in the room were welcome - linen towels and sheets, lovely housekeeping, lots of closet storage, a minibar and functioning AC (very appreciated in the heat.) In the bathroom, we had lovely robes, a nice scale and a bidet. (Oh fun.) We were given a very large room in the original wing, which was also very nice. On the downside - the room was dark with little natural light and rather depressing. The furnishings and decor in our room were surprisingly shabby, drab and depressing for such an expensive and lauded hotel (posted rack rate was over $2000/night). Picky though it seems, the painting of the walls/paneling was really amateurish and sloppy, and looked really tacky. I would fire someone who painted my woodwork like that! The shower curtain was worse than a Motel 6 (not to disparage Motel 6) flimsy and unweighted. Every time I showered, it billowed inwards, sticking to my body. I would cower against the wall and hold it away from my body with one hand whilst scrubbing with the other. Sheesh! Noise traveled easily between the rooms, and we were awakened several times by heavy dragging noises overhead and/or in the hallway. As mentioned previously, no irons or coffee or tea in the room., and ordering room service cost an arm and a leg. And did I mention the food prices? OMG! We went on to the terrace for a drink one afternoon. The view was stupendous. But my cocktail was 24E (over $35) and my husband's beer was over $20. This was ridiculous even for Venice. Lastly, the staff were a strange mix of very kind, helpful people (especially housekeeping, maintenance, porters) and despairingly condescending (concierge! and front desk.) I can't paint everyone with the same brush - there were some front desk and concierge staff that were very friendly and kind. But one or two bad apples really spoiled the whole bunch. All in all, if I were to go back to Venice, and were staying in a similar luxury hotel, I would probably try the Gritti or the Cipriani and hope for a better experience.

Reviews.Title: “Honeymoon in Venice”
Reviews.Author: SFamily87
Reviews.Content: We went to Venice for our honeymoon in late March this year taking our 18 month old little girl. The Danieli is a beautiful hotel, the staff are extremely helpful (nothing is too much trouble) and they love children. The location of the hotel is perfect you are really in the centre of everything. It is expensive though - make sure you book a package with breakfast included we did thankfully! 2 alcoholic drinks at the bar was Â£26. But all of Venice is expensive to eat and drink. Unfortunately the terrace restaurant was being rennovated whilst we where there but I think it's due to open in the summer 08. We got a water taxi to the Hotel on our way out (good fun) , but got the Water bus on return (much cheaper) & you are right by one of the stops so very easy to do. Wonder holiday in a wonderful hotel - just take lots of cash with you!

Reviews.Title: “Nice, but not worth the $$$”
Reviews.Author: usf97j4x4
Reviews.Content: Well, this place is old what can I say. The rooms were nice, clean... but very old - plaster walls cracking, old furnishings. Some of the lower floors are like something out of the Shining... a little creepy but fun to go and spook yourself (they keep the lights dim or off and its empty). They gave us free bottles of wine which was nice. The breakfast, although it costs about $70US was worth it just to sit on the Terrace as the view is unbelieable. The location is great but I actually would have preferred it to be set back from the main drag a little. You walk out of the hotel into a mob of 10,000+ it is a bit hectic.

Reviews.Title: “Nice but some big drawbacks”
Reviews.Author: Pooky-69
Reviews.Content: We just got back from a stay in this hotel. I agree with all of the critical comments listed here. The big pluses: the location is most impressive, right on the main canal, in the center of all the activity in Venice, and right next to the huge shopping area. Other pluses: it's immensely old, like living in an antique, a very interesting place. And the restaurant on the roof terrace offers an unparalleled view of Venice, really magnificent. Now the problems. First was the staff. A mixed situation. Some of the staff are very friendly, helpful, and professional. Too many of the others are haughty, arrogant, obnoxious, and downright snotty. Several times I felt like ripping someone's face off. I do not wish to stay in such an expensive place and be insulted by uneducated workers who fancy themselves licensed to act condescendingly simply because they work there. The air conditioning in the hotel is completely inadequate. The weather in Venice when we were there was cool and the air conditioning was barely adequate. There is no question that this hotel would be unacceptably hot in warm weather. Also due to the canals surrounding thehotel being used as sewers, inside the lobby and other parts of the hotel, on numerous occasions, you could actually smell sewage. I was told that when the water level rises dangerously high, some kind of alarm goes off, and the staff removes all the furnishings from the lobby floor and takes itsomewhere else, then the lobby floods with sewer water, then when it recedes they sterilize it and replace the furnishings. I don't know how true this is but from having stayed on the premises it seems plausible to me. Our room was average size, and had a huge, lovely, all-marble bathroom and a very high ceiling, which I like. The furnishings in the rest of the room were well worn, even shabby, not at all in keeping with five-star hotel status. The air conditioner in the room was weak and noisy, clattering constantly, with bent vanes in the duct. I was so glad the weather was cool, otherwise the room would have been much too warm. The lamps were nice and bright, unlike those in many other hotels that are dim in an effort to control electricity costs (at the expense of dark and depressing rooms), but one of the bulbs was out when we arrived and was never replaced despite numerous cleaning staff visits. The service is also spotty. To my surprise I discovered that due to "fire regulations" (??) they do not provide or allow an iron and ironing board in the rooms, so if your nice clothing was wrinkled during travel and need it needs to be tironed you must ask the staff of the hotel to do it for you (for an outrageous price). I did this, and they never showed up. I called again to the concierge late in the afternoon, who seemed puzzled that it hadn't been done, and then I found that the place where the ironing is done was closed for the night and I would have to wait until morning. This left me with no appealing option for dressing for an evening out. I was not happy with this at all. The windows of our room were shuttered from the outside, allowing no natural light to enter. The room cleaning staff were friendly, helpful, and hard working. So what we have is a very mixed situation. Not sure if I would return.

Reviews.Title: “Location, location, location”
Reviews.Author: leslieinphoenix
Reviews.Content: My sister and I went to Venice in October of 2007 for my job. The hotel was in an amazing location. It has itâ€™s own dock so the water taxi can drive right up, which is a huge selling factor as I saw many tourist walking across town rolling their bags. The hotel was very pretty and old fashion. Our room opened up to a canalâ€“which my father laughed about because anyplace else and it would have been an alley. We often heard singing as the gondola drivers passed by. Our room was very pretty and the bathroom was large enough to handle us both getting ready at the same time! (Not an easy task for doing hair, make up etc.) I would rate the hotel pretty high based upon location, look, comfort, etc. It is not a modern hotel, but when you go to Venice that should not be what you are looking for! There was internet access in the lobby and there is a fee. The hotel and housekeeping staff was great. I would recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to Venice. The location can not be beat!

Reviews.Title: “Terrace closed for renovation”
Reviews.Author: kitkatty
Reviews.Content: A signature feature of this hotel is the bar/restaurant on the rooftop terrace with spectacular views of the lagoon. However, on our arrival, there was a note in the room stating the terrace is closed for renovation until Spring 2009; This means the hotel has no outdoor space, very disappointing as the weather during our stay was beautiful!

Reviews.Title: “Awesome Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: G550
Reviews.Content: Arrived by boat, that pulled right up the the side entrance. Very cool for anyone that has never been to Venice before. Was greeted by very friendly and helpful staff each of the 6 days we were there. You leave your key at the front when you leave the hotel, and by the 2nd day I didn't have to tell them my room number. Made me feel like a celebrity. =) The rooms were very true to the whole Venice feel, and well kept. They did get very hot though! Close your bathroom door and leave the air off. Both pump in a ton of hot air. Great location, great staff, amazing hotel, what more could you want? There are 3 buildings, I had heard that the others were not as nice. We lucked out and did stay in the main building so I can't confirm this. Breakfast was nice but like everything else in Venice.. Pricey (52e) Elevators are scary fun!!!! Highly recommend

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel in Venice”
Reviews.Author: kitty153
Reviews.Content: The hotel Danieli is in the heart of Venice. It's right on the Grand Canal, and is in the perfect location. The inside is grand and stately, and the rooms are lovely and a good size, particularly for european standards. One of the most amazing things about the rooms are the room-darkening shades. Quite helpful for trying to adjust to the time change! We had a wonderful trip to Venice, thanks in part to the hotel Danieli!

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: Hunybee
Reviews.Content: Stayed in the Danieli from 8/3 to 11/3. I was slightly apprehensive after reading some of the reviews but had found a really good deal so went for it and I am so happy I did. On arrival the reception staff were extremely friendly and helpful - we were upgraded to a lagoon view room. It was explained to us that the room was slightly small - I have stayed in small rooms in Venice before and this was palatial - clean, warm, sparkling bathroom, robes and slippers provided, beautifully decorated - and with that fabulous view. We had breakfast in the hotel as it was included in the room price and it was vast with a huge choice of hot and/or cold food, sweet and/or savoury depending upon your choice and greed level. The tea and coffee was piping hot and again the service was impeccable. A note of warning usually breakfast is served in the Terrace Restaurant but owing to the refurbishment currently underway it was served in a ground floor dining room. After being out all day having a cocktail in the bar was a fabulous, relaxing experience......as was having a nightcap on returning after dinner! The concierge was so helpful he managed, after making several phone calls, to locate an art shop for us when we knew the square where the shop was but not its name (nor the name of the square it was in). This is a beautiful, 5 star, traditional hotel in a fabulous location, it is not cheap but nor did I feel "ripped off" by the cost. Everyone working there was efficient, courteous and kind to the utmost degree and I can't wait till I stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Rip off”
Reviews.Author: Susanlubi
Reviews.Content: Went in for afternoon tea with the intention of possibly staying at the Danieli at a later date. After viewing all the cost cutting, ie paper towels in the loo and shabby broken toilets we changed our minds. We ordered a pot of tea which cost a fortune and when it arrived we were given a pot of water and a teabag which we were expected to open and put in the pot ourselves. As the tea bag was not strong enough we asked for another one which we were charged Â£8 euros for. There were no biscuits with the tea and the service was slow and unfriendly. Do yourselves a favour and if you want to go somewhere and be treated to luxury go somewhere else!

Reviews.Title: “Bof (I dunno) as we say in French !”
Reviews.Author: julo
Reviews.Content: We decided to stay at the Danieli because of the great location in central Venice. Indeed, the location is great and very convenient (vaporreto stop to anywhere in the city, including airport, right in front of hotel entrance) but the hotel is old and completely outdated compared to worldwide luxury standards. The room was alright but rather small. The major drawback was the lack of light from the outside. Shutters are closed at all times as the view from the rooms windows is right on other rooms ! So if you expect to spend plenty of time in the room, do not stay here or you will feel deeply depressive... For us, as the weather was georgeous, we spend a minimum amount of time in the room.

Reviews.Title: “A Beautiful Christmas at the Hotel Danieli”
Reviews.Author: Shyoni
Reviews.Content: I had viewed pictures of the Hotel Danieli on travel advisory. I knew of the reputation but was not sure of what to expect of an old hotel. I can only tell you that when I got off of the motor boat and entered the hotel it just took my breath away. It made you feel like you took a step back in time. The lobby was decorated beautifully and in the center of the lobby a Christmas tree stood from floor to ceiling. I reserved my room with twin beds since I was meeting my son who was backpacking in Europe for the Holidays. Two rooms would just be to expensive. Upon arrival I was instructed that I would be upgraded to a larger room at no cost. I was taken to my room and when I entered it was not one but a two room suite. What a great Christmas present for my family. Every day I was surprised with a different treat of fresh fruit, candy, wine and believe it or not flowers for Christmas Day. Christmas is cold but the great thing about December in Venice - you can go anywhere see anything and not wait. Not to mention the great shopping for the Holidays. So many vendors set up all over to sell Christmas gifts. If your going to plan a trip to Venice I would recommend the Hotel Danielle for beauty, service, and of course location location. Yes, it is one of the more expensive hotels but at today's rates everything is expensive in Europe so save and go for it!

Reviews.Title: “A Little Disappointing”
Reviews.Author: HopesandDreams
Reviews.Content: Although as many have stated, the lobby can only be described as amazingly old style grand, the room was not. Our room was tiny, (even by European standards) along with the bathroom. Fortunately, we were paying a hugely discounted rate, and perhaps this accounted for the room selection. There was a hole in the bathroom wall, where a light fixture should have been hanging, and there was also an electrical short in the bedroom light fixture that kept it flickering on and off at random. The room could stand a little refurbishment as there were nicks and paint chips throughout the bathroom. The 13th century luxury room grows old, when you are stepping on your luggage to get out of bed due to the size of the room! However . . . the bedding was superb! The older section of the hotel is currently under renovation and these sounds can be heard beginning at 7:00 AM in the morning. As others have stated, there is an aristocratic air to this hotel, that is sometimes less than inviting. I have also stayed at the Westin Europa, and the Gritti Palace, and found this hotel to be my least favorite of the three Starwood properties. The experience you receive from this hotel will probably be related to how much your total cost are and the value you perceive for these cost. This is an extremely expensive hotel, (i.e. 30 Euro per person for afternoon tea). If you are looking for a grand place, and have grand dollars to spend, I would enjoy this hotel, only for the historic experience, once.

Reviews.Title: “Loved This Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Viceliz
Reviews.Content: Stayed at this hotel for three nights, we loved it. The hotel is in a fantastic location in the heart of Venice for a bit of luxury. Check-in was smooth, the receptionist and concierge were very helpful and friendly. Rooms were of a good size and bathrooms also. This hotel bar and lobby areas are beautiful just beware of the bar prices although this is to be expected in a five star hotel. All in all loved this hotel, just wish we could have afforded a suite!!

Reviews.Title: “IÂ´m sure there are better 5 star hotels in Venice !”
Reviews.Author: ronnstra
Reviews.Content: Very centrally located, just a few metres from Piazza San Marco and very convenient for using the vaporetto boats. However, the whole city of Venice is very beautiful and interesting, and staying a little bit away from the tourist hordes in the San Marco area may make a better Venice experience.. The building is impressive, beautiful and historic and the view from the roof terrace is wonderful. I had a single room, which was OK, and not too small. No view, though. Large selection of italian, american and international food for breakfast. Needless to say, eating on the roof terrace is very expensive. The atmosphere in the hotel is rather pompous. The numerous staff were mecanical, not too friendly or flexible and some of them seemed to be afraid of the guests. At breakfast the waiter cleared the table before I had finished.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Danieli”
Reviews.Author: shawn_broes
Reviews.Content: We had a great experience here, but I read reviews first and knew what to expect. A 5 star hotel, in old Europe terms, The Danieli is an amazing place. Do ask to be in the old building ahead of time. Do have the breakfast there once. It's expensive, so pig out & enjoy! Some of the best food we had. The free hotel boat to the Lido was a must. Next time we'll stay on the Lido, but it was great to stay right in the middle of it all, at a great old hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Historic beautiful hotel, but rooms need TLC...”
Reviews.Author: Mandirae
Reviews.Content: We stayed at The Hotel Danieli for two nights at end of August. Was prepared by other's who have written here about the rooms, but wish more could be done to improve the fate of this historic property. It is listed by the Starwood group as"Luxury Collection." As mentioned the hotel is very grand(once you enter) and lobby/lounge beautifully maintained. There may be rooms here that are more delux than what we were offered, but I imagine there are a fair amount of rooms which were like mine, in need of TLC(tender loving care) or updating. The bathroom looked as if it were "repaired," but not with quality in mind. There were old plastered walls with cracks, worn rug and beds, not "heavenly". We made the best of our stay and tried not to focus on the room. Just felt need to mentioned so you know what to expect. We were there during Venice film festival, so it was very crowded. Liked the location though since close to St. Marks Square and to Public ferry stop. We purchased a 36hrs pass and used it to venture to different areas including the Island of Murano which was a very nice way to spend some time, away from the crowds. At night you can walk to the square for live bands that play to appreciative crowds. Many restaurants in the area. Can just walk around, read menus, and choose one that looks good. Not a big seafood lover, so had to find ones that had meats, poultry, pasta, etc. My daughter is big on Chicken, which was hard to find throughout our travels. As an added bonus, we saw Colin Farrell having a drink in our lobby and Paul Simon walking with family in St. Marks Square. We wanted to take their complimentary shuttle to sister properties on Lido , but told very crowded and pools were closed. Depending on time of year, this would be a nice diversion. The hotel offered us a 20Euro per person breakfast buffet instead of the usual 50Euros. We took advantage of this offer and enjoyed the breakfasts on the rooftop with great views. Really nice way to start your day. Can email me any questions.

Reviews.Title: “If you canâ€™t trust the concierges of the Danieli a 5 star luxury hotel then that”
Reviews.Author: travelsmartSoCal
Reviews.Content: If you canâ€™t trust the concierges of the Danieli a 5 star luxury hotel then that is too bad. So beware scams are waiting!!!! In my opinion the hotel was great in ever aspect except the Danieli being clear on this relationship with the Hotel des Bains and the Excelsior on Lido also the private launch system. I had called the hotel from the airport and told them I was checking in that afternoon and ask what was the best way to get to the hotel and they said a water taxi for 90 euro or about $125.00. They did not offer a Danieli complimentary shuttle from the Airport?? Upon check in â€“ we were not briefed on the Danieli private launch system or (so called private launch system) or the extended link between other hotels. This would have been very good information to have prior to arriving â€“ or being briefed by the check in clerk. All that being said, we used the concierges on our second day when we said we were going to Island of Moreno where the glass is blown and he said he would book a private launch to take us there compliments of the hotel. I thought nice touch and first class then the scam began. So we book this so-called private complimentary launch to the island when we get there and a woman is waiting at the dock. Weâ€™re landing at the back of a building not at a tourist type drop off area â€“ no problem I tip the boat driver and we disembark. She walks us into a glass blowing workshop where there is other tourist sitting around watching men blow glass. We sit down and she starts to explain the process as the one old guy starts to make a small glass horse as she is explaining the details of glass blowing. Then I see a tip jar on the counter â€“ no problem, I tip the old guy when heâ€™s done â€“ still no problem. So now here comes the SCAM and sales pitch â€“ not hard-core as far as I was concerned, but my wife felt uncomfortable and that was enough to prompt me to write this email. She felt scammed and it is a scam so beware of this. A free shuttle is a free shuttle and should not come with strings. This was very disappointing to say the least is a big black eye on the Danieli as far as weâ€™re concerned. We spent about an hour being led from one room to another every room was the sales pitch. We finally ask so where is the exit to the rest of the island was and left to building. So after this we didnâ€™t ask or talk to the concierges for anything else except to hand over or receiving our room key when leaving or entering the hotel. We didnâ€™t want to be sucked into some other scam where someone is getting kick back based on if we bought a 5,000 Euro piece of art. Give me break â€“ so what does this guy think I was born yesterday â€“ if I can afford to stay at the Danieli I might just be wise enough to see a scam coming. Other stuff: The Bar; 10 Euro per glass of wine or about $14.00 US. Hotel coffee for 7 Euro per cup in the room, so go out the main door of the lobby make a right and right go about 200 feet on the right hand side a small shop â€“ youâ€™ll see the water taxi guyâ€™s and other locals there getting their morning goods â€“ Coffee standing at the counter 1 Euro and it was excellent we found this place on day 3. Transportation - after the scam â€“ we used only the waterbus system - white beat up boats with a lot of people on board you canâ€™t miss them they only go one way and you can set your watch by them. They are very easy to figure out and fun. In most cases we were re never ask for a ticket thereâ€™s too many people and if they do ask you for a ticket you can buy one on the boat. You do have to buy 12 Euro ticket per person to go to and from the airport this is a different company â€“ yellow boats and they donâ€™t run as often. Allow a full hour of travel time from the main square to the airport by boat.

Reviews.Title: “Good hotel”
Reviews.Author: travelbugbug
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for two nights Aug 24th and 25th 2007. The hotel was in a great location just a few steps from St. Marks Square. We had a room on the side so we had a view of the side canal but if we stuck our head out a bit further we could see the grand canal, and there was a gondolier that sang every morning that we enjoyed waking up to. However there was also a garbage pickup that came early in the morning that was quite loud. The hotel itself was nice but had a bit of a snobbish feel to it. In general, we found that European standards are much lower than N. American standards in terms of 5-star ratings. For example, the fabric wallpaper was a bit stained, the room was small and our king sized bed was actually two twin beds pushed together (but at least they used one sheet for the whole bed) so donâ€™t be surprised. Once you exit the hotel and start walking towards the Square, take your first right and youâ€™ll come across some really great cafes and stores! We also stayed at the Westin Europa and preferred that hotel over this one. Be sure to take advantage of their complimentary boat ride to Lido beach!

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous hotel - like a beautiful English stately home”
Reviews.Author: TracyACheshire
Reviews.Content: We stayed 3 nights at the Danieli as part of our honeymoon. It definitely has the 'wow' factor for many reasons. The lobby and public areas are breathtaking - you really will be open-mouthed when you first see them. Our bedroom was small and dark (and the bathroom was the smallest I have ever seen!) but given you are in a 14th century palazzo overlooking the Grand Canal - you forgive this! Service was excellent, we had champagne and chocolates in our room on arrival which was a simple but nice touch.. It's VERY expensive, even for venice so beware when ordering food and drinks! We had a problem with our room that the management dealt with swiftly and incredibly professionally - with no quibbles but just a fantastic goodwill gesture from the hotel for the trouble caused. If you want Philip Starke bathrooms with the latest power showers, don't stay at the Danieli. If you want a memorable ventian experience with loads of romance thrown in, then stay here!

Reviews.Title: “The Perfect Hotel for Venice”
Reviews.Author: subatomicpower
Reviews.Content: The hotel was easy and reliable to deal with through our Platium Concierge via Starwood Hotels. The Platinum Concierge and the Hotel Concierge were both reliably polite, informative and extremely helpful. We arrived in Venice and disembarked a very nice Princess Cruise through the Mediterranean that started in Rome. The hotel arranged for a private hosted water taxi from the ship to the hotel for about $140 Euro for my family of 4 (2 young kids) and all our luggage. This proved to be some of the best money I have ever spent! The hostess met us at the ship terminal with a sign with our name on it. We were then ushered with our luggage past the thousands of people desperately looking for transportation, to our own private water taxi. Porters handled the luggage, and we then stretched out in the spacious taxi to enjoy a beautiful view of Venice as we approached the Danieli Hotel. We were driven to a private dock attached directly to the Danieli, and porters arrived to fetch our luggage. The entrance to the hotel (a converted palace) was, well....palatial! The decor was breathtaking, and it made the wait to check in tolerable. The lounge in the hotel entrance was sumptuously appointed and very comfortable. The prices were insane ($20 Euro for a bottle of water), but I got a few bottle of water outside the hotel entrance for $2 Euro, and the bartenders had no issue with that (I personally think that they also thought that the prices were excessive). We could not check in until 4pm, and so we left our luggage to enjoy the beauty of Venice, which was easy, because was were only 1 block away from St. Mark's Square and the amazing shops, restaurants and piazzas that surrounded it. Before we knew it, 4:00 happened, and we returned to our hotel with arms full. We were shown to our rooms, which were breathtaking, sumptuously appointed, and suprisingly large. For about $500 Euro per night per room, we had two connecting rooms. Law prohibits the booking of more than 2 people per room, and we could have easily have had our kids in our room - but what the heck! The view from the room was a canal view, and definitely worth the price. The "Venetian Blinds" were amazing, and I intend to purchase these blinds (that are electronically controlled from the bed tables) for my house! The bathrooms were large, beautifully appointed in natural marble, with towel heaters, etc. The concierge was pleased to send porters with ice buckets to keep our drinks cold, and the hotel provided complimentary bottles of water in each fridge in the rooms. The sheets at the hotel were absolutely amazing, with at least an 800 thread count. The beds were amazingly comfortable, and very large king sized beds. The hotel Concierge was very helpful, friendly and professional. He definitely added to the quality of the stay, and I was pleased to tip him appropriately at the end of our three day stay in Venice. At the end of our stay, the Concierge got us a hostessed private water taxi to the airport, and we were again ushered past thousands of people in line, our luggage handled by porters, and we easily boarded our flights with a minimum of fuss. Again the service cost $140 Euro, but was definitely worth it. The whole thing about Venice is that "you get what you pay for". If you can't afford to stay in "the best" or "nearly the best", you probably should expect to have a less wonderful time than those people that post their experiences when they stay in the nicer places. Venice is probably one of the most expensive cities in Europe. We found the city pristine in cleanliness, and there was no bad smell at all, as there is reputed to be. The people of Venice are cautiously friendly, and take to tourists that don't act like (no offense intended) "stereotypical obnoxious Americans". A polite "Buon Giorno" or "Buono Serra" can get you a great deal in terms of investment in communication and service in this beautiful but sometimes quircky city. Prices for meals in Venice vary from reasonable to insane. I paid $45 Euro for a Bellini at Harry's Famous Bar. The Bellini was terrible, but the nostalgia was nice. Women can dress as they like at Harry's, but men must all wear long slacks, or they are not permitted in. Harry's is like a big ongoing joke: definitely not worth the cost of anything they serve, but worth the cost for the nostalgia for some. No matter what kind of direction sense you have in Venice....you will get lost. It is impossible not to. Just enjoy getting lost, and you cannot fail but to look forward to the next time you get to get lost in this city. The Gondola Ride cost about $100 Euro for 4 people in 1 Gondola. Our Gondolier, "Maximo" was friendly and informative. The 40 minute trip was great, and our kids loved it. We will definitely go back to Venice, but would not think of staying anywhere but the Danieli, in their nicest rooms! I'll add photos of this hotel shortly...... Cheers!

Reviews.Title: “Didnt Dissapoint”
Reviews.Author: andyandmichelle
Reviews.Content: We had a long weekend and we werenâ€™t disappointed with the hotel. Yes it was expensive there but you go to any major city and stay in the finest it has to offer and you will pay for the privilege. We couldnâ€™t fault any part of it. Bedrooms superb and very clean and the bed I give 5* for comfort. We took breakfast in the roof top restaurant and found the quality superb and all very fresh. The staff where all very pleasant and couldnâ€™t do anymore for us. We didnâ€™t have any problem getting a table outside and would recommend it as the view fomm the roof top is spectacular. We had an evening meal on the rooftop on the Sunday night and there are no complaints there either. The menu was well put together and the food was high quality and well very well portioned. If you fancy getting away from the crowded streets then the hotel offer a free taxi to there sister hotel (The Westin Excelsior, Venice Lido Resort) 10 minutes away that has a wonderful beach. You are charged â‚¬20 per person for use of a sun beds and parasol but well worth it. You can hire a beach hut for â‚¬400 but we decided for a few hours that it wasnâ€™t worth it. I tried to think of something that I could fault and to be honest I cant. I know that not everybody will have the same experience that we did but that is just the way things are sometimes. A little tip for those that want to get some good photos is to go out to the sq at about 7 in the morning, its well worth.

Reviews.Title: “Just Amasing”
Reviews.Author: splendidgirl
Reviews.Content: If you want to feel old Venice: close your eyes, don't think about the price, and just book a room at Danieli. It worth it. The view you will get on the Grand Canal is amazing, the room nicely decorated, the bathroom all in marble... ok, the you will probably hate the bed, but you are not in Venice for sleeping. The breakfast is amazing also. Be ready to keep your eyes closed when you pay the 80 euros bill, eat well, enjoy the view and try to remember this moment forever.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel but not cheap”
Reviews.Author: SuzanneUk
Reviews.Content: I had a lovely stay at the hotel but not sure if it was worth the EUR600.00 per night price tag! It is in a great location right on the Grand Canal and only 5 mins walk from St Marks Square. We were luckily enough to be upgraded to a Canal View room which was located on the top floor with the most amazing views of the Grand Canal. The room however was very small and the bathroom even smaller. The roof top terrace has lovely views over the Grand Canal and you can enjoy drinks here in the afternoon and breakfast in the morning. Prepare for the waiters to be a bit slow which should not be expected from a 5 star hotel. The inside of the hotel is stunning which is why I imagine the hotel has such a good reputation. And I'm sure the suites and higher priced rooms are amazing but the standard rooms are nothing special. I'd like to recommend a good restaurant called Taverna Sanlino, close to the Rialto Bridge which we happended to stumble across. They have their own website if you want to check out exactly where it is. All in all Venice is a beautiful city. I loved our trip and would return again but probably not to the Danieli.

Reviews.Title: “Really nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: mammamarg
Reviews.Content: Good clean Hotel centrally situated. Off road parkings which was very welcome as you have to pay to park in designated areas. Staff very helpfull. My second visit here.

Reviews.Title: “Staff was Great”
Reviews.Author: CaliforniaNancy
Reviews.Content: We booked our hotel with AMEX Centurion and the hotel upgraded our rooms which was very nice of them. Between myself, my husband, two teenage girls and a 7 year old, we had 4 bathrooms, a king and three twins in addition to a separate living room. The rooms were a good size, but the hotel is old. The teenage girls had a lot of problems getting into their rooms because you have to hold the key a certain way - due to the oldness of the doors and locks. This created a big problem because they typically had to fetch a maid or someone to open their doors. The staff is the best I have come across in my 18 day trip through France and Italy. The waiters up at the Terrace were very good! As is the front desk. The hotel is old and beautiful, but the bad comes along with that in terms of the oldness and mustiness. I did enjoy my stay there due to the hospital staff, roominess and great breakfast buffet on the Terrace. The location is great! Its so close to San Marco that it's really an ideal spot to be at. We also had water taxis that took us directly to and from the door of the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “New beds needed”
Reviews.Author: billiverstravels
Reviews.Content: The Hotel Danieli has location, location, location, snob appeal, and somewhat disappointing rooms. My main complaint was the uncomfortable (antique?) mattress. From other TripAdvisor comments, I see we are not alone in this regard. A Luxury Collection hotel, part of the Starwood properties, should have beds of quality equal to the "heavenly beds" which make Sheraton stays so pleasant. We stayed in the main buidling and our room on the fourth floor was small, clean and very quiet (you can't complain about hearing the gondoleers... this is Venice after all). The food and service in the rooftop Terrazza restaurant was terrific and they are not shy about charging for it. However, only a spendthrift would consider breakfast buffets for the family at 52 Euros each. The concierge staff was amazing. They were always incredibly busy but always served well. When, on our first night there, we found the restaurant could not accommodate us, we were given a recommendation for another restaurant we found to be superb. The shuttles provided to other Starwood properties were nice perks. Wouldn't a shuttle from the airport or train station be wonderfully welcoming?

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel if you get an upgrade!”
Reviews.Author: renae29
Reviews.Content: I'm sure others have said this before me, but the main building of the hotel is beautiful. But most people are not lodged in that building, most guests are placed in this ugly, old "newer" building. The "newer" building was built in the 1960's i think and is a huge eyesore. It's also pretty moldy smelling and has the overall quality of a 3 star hotel. We were upgraded to a suite in the new building that had a balcony and a gorgeous view of the bay. but the beds were lumpy and the mattressed seemed like they were about 20 years old. I hope the have since replaced the them. The furniture was really worn and the carpets smelled and were pretty cheap. The hotel needs a massive renovation!

Reviews.Title: “Superb stay”
Reviews.Author: JohnSwansea_U_K_
Reviews.Content: May I start by saying that I have no connection whatsoever with any establishment that I mention here however as I stay many weeks of the year in hotels around the world of 4 or 5 star I feel justified in making comment. It was with some trepidation that I took my wife to the Danieli as I had read many negative reports on this site and did think to change to the Cipriani or the Gritti Palace however my travel agent who had been there recently advised me to choose this hotel. We found the staff efficient and charming, were escorted to our room overloking the lagoon and gifts of champagne and chocolates were sent to us. As we were late arriving we had room service which was prompt and the food was of a high standard. The room itself was in the manner of the hotel in that it had old furniture but all the facilities worked and there was no sign whatsoever of loose electrical fittings or rustng screws which I had read of from other writers. The bed was superbly comfortable. Breakfast on the terrace was a most enjoyable experience with plenty of food and a selection to meet the most fastidious of palates, one piece of advice beware the thieving birds who will take whatever you have if you turn your back! The view is magnificent. We also had dinner there one evening and had no complaints whatsoever, the service and food was excellent with some good wines by the glass, ask for the separate list from the bar. Housekeeping was so efficient that our room was usually serviced whilst we were at breakfast. The only negative that we experienced was on checking out which took an eternity and we had to ask three times for our bags to be collected from our room. We also ate at the Gritti Palace and found it very good at lunchtime and at a real find theTrattoria Alla Madonna in a street of that name near the Rialto Bridge walk past the ones next to the Grand Canal and turn right down a small street, what a superb experience this turned out to be at a remarkably low cost. General advice: Ensure you have private transfers to and from the airport and your hotel arranged in advance I booked through Burgess Travel in Swansea we were met and escorted but it must be a nightmare to just arrive and try to find your own way!; Visit the lovely island of Burano by vaporetto (not Murano totally different experience) and finally don't waste your money going to Harry's Bar this was the low point of our whole Venetian experience a poor meal, I think it can only be famous for being famous perhaps like some of the clientele?

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing Danieli”
Reviews.Author: TrustyTraveller61
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from a 3 night stay at the Danieli. It was a surprise for me from my husband to celebrate our 7th Wedding Anniversary and we had great expectations, but unfortunately we left feeling rather disappointed with the Danieli experience overall. The hotel is in a fantastic location and the views from the breakfast terazza are simply " to die for ". The entrance hall, lobby area etc is very impressive, you can just feel the history. However, beyond that the bedrooms and the standard of service certainly don't match the "Italian hotel Royalty" hype that the Hotel's website would have you believe! We have stayed in all standards of hotels all over the world, we particularly love travelling to Italy, but i would not award the Danieli its Luxury 5 star label. Perhaps if one was staying in the 4000 Euro per night suite, then the room would be a better standard, but how many people get that opportunity? Judging by some fellow Trip Advisors photos I think our bedroom was actually more spacious and more traditionally furnished. However, the fact remains, the room and particularly the bathroom, desparately need some money spending on them in order to upgrade them to a better standard and a LOT of money to reach 5 star standard.

Reviews.Title: “It's elegance faded a long time ago and apart from the lobby it's now a tatty 4*”
Reviews.Author: WibblyWobblyMan
Reviews.Content: Someone commented that if you're looking for American 5* it's not the place for you. If you ask me, if you're looking for any sort of 5* it's not the place for you. It may have a famous lobby, but how much time will you spend in the lobby? Unless you're in a â‚¬3,000/night suite that's about all you'll get of the 5* experience. Okay, good points first. It has a beautiful lobby and bar, and some of the large landings upstairs with mirrors and old paintings wouldn't look out of place in a museum. Breakfast on the terraza is nice, you have a great view of the island opposite and the lagoon - if you can get a table. but â‚¬110 worth of nice for two people? Not in my book. The location is great, next to San Marco and the Doge's Palace, (but any hotel in San Marco is only 5 mins walk away) The chandeliers in the rooms are nice murano glass antiques, even if broken and/or hanging off the walls. If that's all you want from a hotel, Venice is the only place you can go in Italy, it's either free with SPG points or you don't care how much it is, or you just want to show off, then it's the place for you. Now I haven't stayed anywhere else in Venice, so I suspect that - relatively - it is the best hotel in Venice. Venice isn't the nicest place in Italy by a long way though. The view from any 4* hotel terrace on Via Capo in Sorrento beats the Danieli hands down; the grand canal isn't a patch on a restaurant terrace looking over the pretty town of Sorrento, the deep blue of the Bay of Naples and Mt. Vesuvio in the distance. But, for me, the good bits end there. As a hotel to stay in, it does not justify it's reputation. The location and lobby/bar are what make it a 5* hotel. In every other respect, it's a good 4* We were, it seems, lucky; we had a room that overlooked the side canal. You could end up in the new part which looks, from the outside, like any other chain hotel. However if you're on the side canal, expect to be woken up by the refuse collections at 8am. The narrow space between the buildings magnifies the racket of bottles and the rubbish compactor. The room itself was tatty. It's not a case of 'faded elegance' or 'shabby chique', it's just tatty. The bath itself was too small to get a shower; the shower curtain must have cost less than 10â‚¬. The screws holding the marble tiles were rusty. It probably looked very nice 20 years ago, but no more. The room itself was big enough, and it had a couple of nice antique bits of furniture. The linen on the beds was nice and clean and the beds were comfy. The air-conditioning sort of worked, but it was cooler with the windows open which let the mosquito's in. They'd be better off with ceiling fans. The corridors were dark and dingy; whatever gilted plasterwork and pictures had once lined it were gone, and the walls were painted in several shades of beige. The rugs on the floor slipped when yo stood on them, and the lights on the walls were literally hanging off in a few places. The breakfast, was a disgrace. They supposedly serve until 10.30 but after 10, don't expect there to be anything left. We didn't have to pay for it (it was included), but if they'd asked me for â‚¬50/person per day I'd have refused to pay. One American chap complained that it was no better than a canteen, and he was right. What food there was had been out for a long time, and the self-service area was messy. For â‚¬55 a hea I'd have expected to have ordered breakfast to be cooked fresh and brought to me whilst still hot, not to be picking at the poached eggs to see if thre were any left that hadn't gone hard, or fishing around in the grease to see if there was any bacon that wasn't burnt. Any bacon at all would have been nice one day! It could be argued that we should have complained; if it had been one or two little things I would have. But in a 5* hotel, you shouldn't have to, and when so many things are wrong, it shows that the level of service is bad all round and all the time and you're wasting your breath. I don't goto a 5* hotel to spoil my stay by having to complain. There was a queue for terrace tables, I know there's only so many but they just left people standing in a queue. Italians were guided past the queue to any empty tables, everyone else had to wait their turn. I don't expect to be left standing in a queue in a 5* place, at least they could have offered to get us some coffee or a drink or something. Given that lunch/dinner was going to be no better (and reading the comments here that seems to be true), we didn't waste our money. YOu can find nice places to eat for a fraction of the cost 5 minutes away. The same applies to the bar; we figured from the room minibar that the bar prices would be astronomical, and again you can find nice bars round the corner. Even Harry's bar was cheaper for a bellini than a martini here. Just walk past San Marco and the gardens and vaporetti stops and it's on your right. Minibar prices: â‚¬8 for a can of coke, â‚¬18 for a miniature of chivas regal, â‚¬8 for a small tube of pringles. Room service prices - â‚¬30 for a cheese and ham toastie, and that's the cheapest thing on there! If you do go to the Danieli, go out and right, take the first small street on the right, 50yds down there's a snackbar that sells canned/bottled drinks and nice fresh panini for 1/10th the price!

Reviews.Title: “The lobby is beautiful but it ends there”
Reviews.Author: Enjoythemoment
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Danieli only because I used Starwood points. I didn't want to pay $1000 a night. I'm glad I didn't. This is a 600 year old palace in a perfect location and with one of the most beautiful entries and lobbies of any hotel but... The rooms were average at best and noisy. I will say that the staff was helpful. Avoid lunch at the rooftop terrace. 40 euro cover charge for our family on top of incredible prices. All I can say is that I stayed at the Danieli - once.

Reviews.Title: “Old World Elegance”
Reviews.Author: TravelTwinkie
Reviews.Content: After 4 weeks in B&B's and ferries, the Danieli was a haven of elegance. We were staying on SPG points, and were treated like honored guests, escorted to our beautiful room, welcomed with a bottle of wine, checked in at only 2:30 pm - the reception was all good. Then we discovered what we think is the best feature of our room - we are on a quiet interior courtyard which only the experienced traveler might appreciate but it really eliminates the noise level common in European cities. The room was beautiful with a marble bath, a real bathtub, and fabric upholstered walls. At times we thought we were alone in the building. The front desk and concierge staff were mostly friendly and helpful, and got us tickets to "Music at the Palazzo" without holding out their hands. We took advantage of the launch to the Lido to see the other two hotels in the SPG offerings, and of the free launch to Murano (though we ducked out of the offered tour of the glass factory). We did spend an astronomical $55 for two drinks on the terrace, but it really was a unique and wonderful experience that should not be missed. We skipped the ridiculously priced breakfast buffet, but who wouldn't at 60euros. We used the internet service at 5 euros for 15 minutes only because it was easier than hunting for an internet cafe. We would call this a wonderful end to our 4.5 weeks in Italy and Croatia and would return (on points) in a heartbeat. We're adding a new rule to our travel guidelines - always end a long trip with a 5-star hotel stay.

Reviews.Title: “Magnificent, centrally located glorious hotel!”
Reviews.Author: natc143
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the hotel Danieli for our 1st anniversary. Fabulous hotel, great location! Would return again for sure! Due to flooding our taxi could barely get under the bridge to get us to our hotel, but with some VERY SWIFT maneuvering, we made it. I was a bit nervous with all handling of our "heavy" luggage, but they managed it quite well. Arriving into the Danieli, slightly jet lagged we were in AWE of the four story GRAND foyer. (Iâ€™ll attach a link to our pictures in another post). It was breathtaking and worth every penny hehe. Check in was smooth and we arrived at our hotel room with a complimentary bottle of champagne and truffles since it was our anniversary. We were happy! Our room was an inside room about 30 sq meters, room 221. It was beautifully decorated including a white marble bath. It was the smallest room weâ€™ve ever stayed in, but we expected it! I must say the amenities, dÃ©cor and location did make up for the short comings in the room size. We had a great blow dryer (which was a relief since my converter and adapter didnâ€™t work). They had a towel warmer in the bathroom, slippers, robes (of course) and a vanity stool for me to sit on when getting ready. The TV and stations were actually the best we had for our trip, but that was not saying much at all. There was 3 english channels and cnn was one of them. I guess weâ€™re not on vacation to watch TV but its something weâ€™re used to in New York. The FIRST night we ate at our hotel the Danieli at the rooftop restaurant with some of the best views of the Grand Canal. My husband Chris enjoyed his risotto immensely but I was disappointed with the John Dory I ordered (which is one of my favorite fishes). The service was great but as advised, some of the best meals in Venice, and in Italy are not at hotels, they are at Osteriaâ€™s and Trattorias. This is unlike New York and was something valuable I learned on my trip thanks to all here. That evening we had drinks and listened to music at the Danieli Bar. It was incredible! The martiniâ€™s were (gasp) 20 euros and higher. But if youâ€™re staying there I guess weâ€™re not supposed to gasp about the price hehe. You will not be disappointed with this incredible hotel! Book early for better rates (we really got a lower rate).

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Hotel for Venice if you can afford it.”
Reviews.Author: AVeryPickyTraveler
Reviews.Content: I have read a lot of the other not so favorable reviews of this hotel and almost cancelled my reservation because of them. I am so glad I didn't (maybe the poor reviews lowered my expectations and that is why I liked it). This is without a doubt a nicely furnished, luxury hotel. This hotel is what all the other chains (Intercontinental, etc.) aspire to be but fall short. I will admit that there is no way I would spend 600 Euro a night to stay here. (more of a budget thing than a reflection of the hotel.) I used my rewards points to pay for a night at this hotel and it absolutely made my trip to Venice complete. It cost me a lot (for the rewards points used for one night here, I could have had 3 nights at most other hotels). However luxury is worth it. My room was nicely decorated ... there were some spots where the room could have used a little paint, etc. but overall it felt clean and very spacious. In Venice, this is a surprise ... at another hotel chain's hotel in Rome I could have fit 2 of those rooms in my one room at the Danieli. Maybe it was because I was in the main building (the pink one) ... as there are two other buildings (white ones) on each side that the hotel owns ... but I didn't see anything that was glaringly bad about the upkeep or furnishings in the hotel. In fact, even the common areas of the hotel have amazing works of art hanging there. A lot of people complain about how expensive this hotel is (it is true that a meal for one person at the restaurant will cost around 60 - 80 Euros for an entre and drink FOR LUNCH ... the water or soda alone is 9 Euro!!!) however, keep in mind that if the prices were more reasonable the crowds of tourists that make the streets unbearable in Venice would crowd the tables at the rooftop restaurant making it less exclusive. The view from the restaurant is AMAZING! It is a complete panorama of the lagoon. The service is great (a little on the snooty side if you are a younger person) and the food is among the best I had in Venice. They have entrees such as steak to scorpion fish. You really must get at least one meal in on the rooftop restaurant ... I suggest lunch on a nice day. (If you have starwoods points, for 4,500 points they will give you a free lunch if you ask the concierge to arrange it.) The location of the hotel is spectacular. It is right next to the Vaporado (ferry boat/subway boat) and you can use the hotel's shuttle to go to the beach or the other Sheraton properties. You are only a short walk (less than a block) from St. Mark's Square where you can have a drink at night while an orchestra plays. I would highly recommend anyone who has the extra points or money to disregard most of the reviews of this hotel because I am a very picky traveler and honestly, this was one of the best stays I've had in Italy. Although rooms with a Lagoon view are almost impossible to get for under 1000 Euro, the room I had was a standard room and I had a canal view. The Gondolas would pass right under my window and occasionally a Gondola with an accordian would pass by, which made a perfect feeling of Venice. If I stuck my head out the window, I could see the lagoon. Overpriced? Maybe. But if you are looking for luxury and exclusivity, the Danieli is your hotel! I looked at the Gritti Palace and the Weston Europa ... both also owned by Sheraton ... and the Danielli was by far the best overall in its location, charm and restaurants. When you check in, if you want to visit the other restaurants or bars at these hotels, they give you a card which you can charge any meal or drink to your room in the Danieli. A FANTASTIC HOTEL!!! Don't miss this one while you are in Venice!

Reviews.Title: “Second time to the fabulous Danieli”
Reviews.Author: jdf3361
Reviews.Content: This is my second stay at the Danieli. It dumbfounds me that many people rate the Danieli so poorly! It IS expensive, it IS weathered, BUT it is a grand old hotel that effectively equates to staying in a museum. If you want an American 5 star hotel experience, then the Danieli is not your place. If you want luxurious accomodations, in the heart of things, don't mind that some areas the wear is showing, then the Danieli IS the hotel in Venice. Food is horrendously expensive (4 course dinner will set you back about 150+ Euro). I rarely eat meals at the hotels where I stay and it is quite easy to walk two doors down to the Londra Palace and enjoy a nice meal for 35 Euros, breakfast buffet there for 18 Euro. My rate was discounted - even at 385 Euro/night. The room had luxurious bedding, fabric walls that matched the drapers and chairs, a view of the grand canal, an air conditioner that worked quite well and a complimentary bottle of wine. Also, on a very positive note was that the personnel this trip were far from "snooty" and were entirely gracious and helpful. Another huge plus is free water taxi service to Murano as well as to the Lido. These trips alone on a private taxi would set you back 200 Euro round trip. Are there more modern hotels in Venice? - yes. Are there hotels with more gracious history and class - I personally think not.

Reviews.Title: “great experience”
Reviews.Author: onthegoNYC
Reviews.Content: Was nervous about staying at the Danieli after reading all the reviews. I was very pleasantly suprised that my experience was outstanding. The front desk took us to our rooms for our approval. The restaurants that were recommended were great, and I found the staff throughout the hotel warm and friendly. The room was dated, but not musty or dirty. I am an experienced traveller, stayed at the best hotels, and have nothing to complain about after our stay at the Danieli

Reviews.Title: “"Luxury Collection" Complete Misnomer”
Reviews.Author: Travel2DC
Reviews.Content: Like other reviewing the Danieli, I expected the hotel to be a grand end to my European vacation. However, the pictures and description completely belie the reality of our stay. The best that I can offer is that we had a Deluxe room with a good amount of square footage. Beyond size, the furniture paint was chipped, the fabric-lined walls were stained, the carpets were dirty, the room was generally dusty & musty and the bathroom room was outdated. And, based on common spaces in the hotel, I would surmise that this holds true for other rooms. Also, during the course of the stay, we found the staff to be lacking in professionalism. Like a stacked airport runway, the concierge was sending guests â€“ one after another â€“ to the same disappointing restaurant; he made no attempt to understand the dining needs and nuances of his requestors. More disappointing, we returned to our room early one day and found housekeeping rummaging through our bags. They had pulled out our travel magazines and were reading them to each other. We reported this to the front desk, but no reported action was taken. In all, this was a very lackluster experience from a self-described, â€œluxury collectionâ€� hotel. I would strongly recommend going to another location for a better Venetian experience.

Reviews.Title: “No right to fly the "luxury collection" flag!”
Reviews.Author: PaxtonKaufman
Reviews.Content: This hotel needs a total overhaul! The rooms are dated and in poor condition (torn carpeting, chipped and dirty paint) and the staff is indifferent to their guests. I've heard they are closing soon to renovate...save your money and stay elsewhere until they improve the condition of the rooms and invest in training for their staff.

Reviews.Title: “Trading on past glories - avoid at all costs !!!”
Reviews.Author: ballymoreboy
Reviews.Content: This was meant to be a highlight but unfortunately this was the abject disappointment. The service was appalling. A waiter in the very overpriced terrace restaurant was actually chewing gum on the floor. The food was average beyond belief. !! Absolute apathy from the staff who are unprofessional and lacking any real joy. Venice is stunning ..The Danieli show be the jewel in the crown. However it is a drap piece on tinsel washing up against the Grand Canal .. Such a pity ......

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, but overrated”
Reviews.Author: pcinbk
Reviews.Content: Beautiful setting and views (if you're lucky), so-so service.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel living on past glory”
Reviews.Author: claudio10
Reviews.Content: When we arrived at The Danieli we were shown to a room which instantly smelled very musky and old so we asked to move room and the other room was far better. This hotel is definitely over rated and is nothing like a 5 star. The toilets on the ground floor are really grotty and yuk and to be honest we didnt even fancy using them as they were so old and dirty. I cannot understand why they dont spend some much needed money on the place. Breakfast was nothing special at all and below average but the rooftop terrace had nice views. I would urge trip advisor members to ask to move bedrooms if they are given a musky smelling room as some rooms are much better than others. Hotel is greatly overpriced.

Reviews.Title: “Go for quaint for star with some peace and quiet”
Reviews.Author: TVJ
Reviews.Content: The Danieli is more hype that real firze star or true Venice experience. The location is ground zero for large tour groups and street vendors. Lound, crowded, and lacking any charm in the immediate area and Venice is FULL of charm. Hotel is worn and in desperate need of updating, even just basic painting. We are gold Starwood members and were not offered an upgarde and the front desk acted insulted that we asked. The conceirge staff is that of a very basic Hilton---friendly but no follow up regarding dinner reservations. However, they did warn us not to belive anyone outside the hotel doors offering us any services--that they were not affliated with the hotel. We were charged over 100 euros for a rollaway bed in our room for our 12 year old to find that the small couch had a pullout bed but were told it would still be an additiona 100 Euro charge to our already 648 eruo rate for a canal view room. Canal view room was really about 30 feet back from the canal with all of the vendors (that begin setting up and yelling back and forth to each other at 7 am). You can do MUCH better with a quaint four star on a side canal. Although the view across the canal is beautiful, the quaint side canals are much more Venice. One of the reasons I chose this hotel was because of he roof top terrace/bar. We went up to have a drink and watch the sun set and were told the bar was not open to anyone who was not also having dinner---unbelievealbe! No apology, not explaination, just sternly told it was not for us. When pointed out that we were hotel guest they simply replied that it was ot open--it was open just not to us. Overall, very disappointed. Starwood folks need to make a site visit and see the overall condiiton of the property (there is a difference between quaint Venice and run down). When you check in there is no orientaitont othe property--you are on your own. Venice was wonderful--this Starwood property is just not in the right place or with the right people working there. Read the other review---find somewhere that is the real Venice!

Reviews.Title: “Deplorable Service in a hotel with no A/C”
Reviews.Author: Mr_MrsPickyPicky
Reviews.Content: Every service request is met with "Sorry, but it's impossible". Zero smiles. Zero common sense. Zero service. Rooms sweltering hot during the day and no A/C to be found. Comfy Starwood beds though...

Reviews.Title: “A grand old lady”
Reviews.Author: Lori S
Reviews.Content: Overall, my stay at the Danieli in May following a cruise was very special. It was my first visit to Venice, which made it especially amazing. I checked in around 11am and my room was not ready but they said it would be ready shortly, so I stepped outside the hotel and was promptly approached to take the free boat ride to Murano. I read about this here and there so I was prepared, and since I love art glass I wanted to go there anyway. I actually loved the semi-private (me and another couple) trip to Murano. We enjoyed the demonstration and toured the incredible display rooms and then we were whisked back to Venice without any problems. It was a very special introduction to the back "alleys" and waterways of Venice. I arrived back to the Danieli around 12noon and the room was "almost" ready. I kept checking back and in about a 1/2 hour more and a little prodding, I was graciously escorted to my room in the old section. I was on the third floor above the extraordinary lobby. My room was elegant and charming but worn....definitely in need of an update. Maybe a new area rug to cover the bedroom floor would have made all the difference. The linens were luxurious. The bathroom was in the same condition. I was prepared for this after reading all of the reviews pre-trip, so I did not let this ruin my stay at the Danieli. My room was overlooking one of the side canals and my window opened up fully so I could clearly look out and see the gondolas floating 3 floors below.........it was fabulous. The gondoliers songs were echoing up the alley to my room....very charming. This side was very quiet and all I could hear in the morning was the church bells. The location of the hotel was perfect. Breakfast and afternoon tea was included in my package. The outdoor breakfast restaurant was overlooking the main lagoon and it was breathtaking. The breakfast buffet was plentiful and delicious. Afternoon tea in the lobby was also delicious and special. I am looking forward to my next visit to Venice and I would not hesitate to stay here again, however, there are other hotels in Venice that I would like to try next time. All of the staff that I encountered were very professional and pleasant. I highly recommend taking the private boat service from the hotel to the train station. That final trip up the canal on my private boat was very convenient and special, and well worth the fare.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Stay”
Reviews.Author: lejon
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the Danieli for a Valentines long weekend. When we arrived our booking had not been sent through by the company we had booked with. We had booked a suite overlooking the lagoon and there was none available for that night. The staff could not have been nicer or more helpful. They put us in another room for the night and gave us complimentary champagne and chocolates and the next day took our bags to our new room while we went sight seeing. The rooms were perfect and beautiful with wonderful views of the lagoon. Again there was an other bottle of champagne and chocolates for us. We ate in the restaurant one night and it was expensive but the food was lovely and the staff were extremely friendly. It was the best holiday we have ever had and the Danieli was one of the main reasons. We could not fault the hotel or the staff. We look forward to going back soon.

Reviews.Title: “Don't stay there until it's upgraded!!”
Reviews.Author: Katelyn_Shyle
Reviews.Content: We were very disappointed with the hotel as the whole place was in need of upgrading. We were staying in Room 33 and were told, only after we've checked in, that the air conditioning for the entire hotel is turned off from beg. of Oct till Dec!! We ended up having a terrible night as there was no ventilation (we tried opening the windows, but it was too noisy outside, even into the wee hours of morning). The floors creaked with every step and they didn't provide complimentary drinking water. Bed and pillows were also v.v. uncomfortable. Also, we paid a high price to stay in a room that overlooked the canal. what we were not told was that the window was tiny, we couldn't get a view, and it was a very very busy street (hence the constant noise level) After 2 sleepless nights, we checked out and moved into the Hotel Bauer. (recommended by friends we called up). You guys should check that out! the rooms were fantastic! and our walk-in rate was even cheaper than the early bird rate we paid for Hotel Danieli. Its standard room had high ceilings, a big, clean bathroom (with an independant shower area), comfortable bed, with a fantastic view of the canal. it's location was also very good and they have much better service than Danieli Hotel!!

Reviews.Title: “Grand But In Need Of Updating”
Reviews.Author: Len-Monica
Reviews.Content: In Venice Oct Of 2006 ....Stayed at the Westin Regina last year same time. Felt better overall at the Westin....But there is something to be said for the grand show of this old stately Hotel Danieli. Found everything average..Felt it was time to fix the place a bit..everything was a bit ragged at the edges. Location great...no complaints about staff or service....but know praises either. So my average overal experience is just that. By the way I note other travlers complaining about price vs value on many properties like this one. Shop them early and deal direct with the Hotel. $$$ Values a plenty to be had at all of the best Hotels with a bit of effort and early bookings.

Reviews.Title: “A special favorite, even with flaws.”
Reviews.Author: el_midnite
Reviews.Content: Venice's Danieli Hotel is a grand palace of a hotel, Venice as it was and probably will never be again. Comprising three distinct structures, it does matter which one has your room, including the 14th century palace, 18th century palace, and a 20th building that also holds the restaurant. In a nutshell, this place is magnficient, but not perfect. I've stayed in some great places and this ranks very near the top. In terms of romantic appeal and history, nothing beats it.
